text:
today on Hot Thai Kitchen we're making Tom Yum Goong 
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen today

we're making possibly the most famous soup in 
Thai cuisine making tom yum now let's look at

the name tom means to boil so in a dish name it's 
an indication that it's a soup YUM actually refers

to a category of tied salads so in a way tom yum 
means salad soup which might seem strange but it's

because the soup uses the exact same seasoning 
ingredients as the salad and now because of spot

prawn season in Vancouver where I'm living right 
now uh we're making tom yum goong or tom yum

with prawns so let's get started so first to 
talk about liquids I got here four quarts of

shrimp stock and I have a video on how to make 
shrimp stock but you can also just use water or

chicken stock okay to that I'm going to add the 
herbs I'm going to add what I call the Trinity

the tom yum Trinity first we're using lemongrass 
lemongrass sometimes comes trims and everything

but sometimes it comes all like this so how you 
prep it is you first cut off the top drive it

and then you cut off the bottom and then there's 
usually a loose dry layer that you're also going

to remove so this is where the flavor is is 
where the flavor is concentrated and you're

going to smash it first with the back of your 
knife now this releases the flavors break the

cells of the plant and releases the flavors into 
the soup more easily and then we're going to just

cut it into chunks that goes into the soup and 
the next we're going to have galangal galangal

is a rhizome and it may look like a ginger but 
it's very different and it's not substitutable

the flavors like you galangal is cooling plate 
flip flavor whereas ginger is a hot flavor the

smell of galangal reminds me of lush pine forest 
so we're not going to use this part we're going to

use seven to eight thin rounds of this part it's 
small so I'm just adding some extra and that goes

actually that looks kind of small usually at seven 
to eight about this size I have a couple more and

then finally we have our kaffir lime leaves now 
kaffir lime leaves look just like this these have

actually been frozen that's how I store that when 
so when you buy them there's usually more than you

can use just keep them in freezer in a ziplock 
bag the last you forever so just five to six

leaves and you're just going to bruise them by 
tearing them and by doing this you bruise them

and it helps them release their flavors into the 
soup and then lastly our spice some Thai chilies

now I'm not going to finely chop this but I will 
just kind of bruise it a little bit just crush

it and these have also been frozen that's how I 
keep my Thai chilies maybe cut it in two pieces

and add that in there now I didn't want to like 
cut them into small pieces because I do want them

to be visible I don't want people to accidentally 
take in a piece of chopped chili and that's going

to be really really spicy this way I Bruce it it 
releases its spice as it infuses but there's a big

chunk so people can know to avoid them so I'm 
going to let this come to a boil and then let

it simmer it doesn't take a very long time a few 
minutes after it's coming to a boil do be able to

smell it really well and meanwhile let's prep our 
other ingredients so the other ingredients I've

got oysters mushrooms here about three cups the 
big ones I just split them into bite-size pieces

you can use other kinds of Asian mushrooms such 
as enoki mushroom or shimeji or beech mushrooms

work really well don't use the button mushrooms 
so they don't do as well in soup as we've got that

and next our prawns or shrimp so I've got spot 
prawns here they came into life and they're dead

now so what I did to prep them is I tear off the 
head and the head I save for making shrimp stock

which I already did and then spot prawns when 
they're fresh and raw it's really hard to peel so

I'm just going to leave the peel in but if you're 
using regular prawns you can just peel everything

and take them add them to your shrimp stock now I 
cut the back down so it's easier to eat and then

I'm going to use a paring knife and then butterfly 
it open it up a little bit more check to see if

there's any veins this one doesn't have any veins 
and that'll make it cook faster it also be easier

for people to have peel when they go to eat it 
okay so I've got about eight of them right here

you can use more if you want this recipes for four 
so you can just think you know how much how many

shrimp per person you want to add so let's look 
at our seasoning as I mentioned these seasonings

are the same as in a young or Thai salad first our 
salting agent we have fish sauce 3 tablespoons of

fish sauce and our sour agent we've got half a cup 
of lime juice it's about two to three juicy limes

you've got a little bit of steak to just round 
out the acid and the salt about a teaspoon or

two of sugar I started with one and you can always 
taste an add now the next ingredient you probably

have this if you've been to Thai restaurants 
this would probably be in your thumb yeah but

it's actually an optional ingredient it's Thai 
chili paste it's called an unpaid Powell and

the jar comes like this it says chili paste with 
soybean oil we it's a relatively new thing the

old rustic style of thumb yum does not contain 
shrimp paste but if you're going to add and only

add it if you're making something with shrimp 
because this is made from shrimp and it'll have

a shrimpy flavor or add shrimpy flavor to every 
you make so when we make some young chicken or

some young fish or other kinds of some young we 
actually don't do this we don't include that and

that's another thing in Thailand when you're 
making some young guy which is something of a

chicken or throw me on black.we it's not just 
a matter of switching out protein for another

the seasoning and the herbs actually change a 
little bit too but that's for another time so

that's all our seasoning and now we're gonna the 
soup is boiling now so let's go back to the soap

so the soups tend simmering now and if you use 
water you'll be able to tell that the water will

start turning a little bit yellowish or greenish 
and you can smell it that's how you know so it's

done here and I do need to say that these herbs 
are for infusing purposes only okay they're really

tough to chewy and they're not meant to be eaten 
Thai people usually leave them in for garnish and

it makes a little pretty but if you're serving it 
to an on-time make sure you either tell them that

do not eat these herbs or you can remove them 
at this stage where it's done infusing just use

a slotted spoon and just take them out okay okay 
so we're going in first with the oyster mushrooms

and then we're going to let it kind of come back 
to a boil so after it's come back to a boil then

you're going to go in with your shrimp and now 
you're just going to stir to split them apart a

little bit and then after about fifteen thirty 
seconds that come back to a boil a little bit

I'm going to turn it off and the reason why 
I'm going to turn it off is because this is

really hot and we've already butterflied 
our shrimp so if I cook it all the way

I'm actually going to overcook it with the 
residual heat that's still in the pot if I

let the shrimp sit in this hot water in 
about a minute or so it's just going to

be perfectly cooked and we're not going to 
risk overcooking it okay so now that that's

done we're going to go in with our seasoning 
line and once you've added the lime you don't

want to cook it because if you cook lime it 
actually kind of ruins the flavor of fish sauce

the chili paste and the sugar started making 
sure that the chilli paste is all dissolved

smells very good so now we're going to taste 
it always always taste your food because when

you're cooking with lime every lime has different 
acidity every fish sauce every brand of fish sauce

has different saltiness and especially when it 
comes to soup the amount of water that evaporates

there's a lot of variables that go into it in 
so you always taste and adjust accordingly so

what you're looking for the leaf flavor should 
be sour and the salt in the sweet is followed by

the salt and the sweet is just kind of there to 
round off everything and the spiciness should be

obvious so this is a lot of kind of dish where 
it's mild so the chili needs to play a leading

role I want you to say alright let's go and plate 
it up it's not going to all fit that's okay and as

you can see the herbs actually make a very pretty 
garnish and then the shrimp heads I saved from my

shrimp stock making earlier these actually work 
perfect as garnish now you know it's nice every

once in a while to be able to see the animal 
you're eating in the eye and and be connected

to your food that way most of the time food and 
stars come now with no heads fuels already gone

no feet no nothing is just pre-trimmed edible 
parts and it's nice that once in a while to

see what they really look like a little bit 
of cilantro garnish and then we're done our

tom yung goong and thanks for tuning in I'll 
see you next time for your next delicious time
